urls.title: Cleaning Up with Michael Liebreich / Episode 31 - Emma Howard Boyd
urls.description: Emma Howard Boyd is one of the leading voices the UK‚Äôs Environment scene. As the Chair of the Environment Agency, she is at the forefront of the current environment agenda. This week, Michael and Emma will discuss everything from recent flooding in the UK to the unique UWC schooling experience.

urls.title: Council news | Suffolk County Council
urls.description: Water would normally be pumped away into Suffolk‚Äôs River Deben, is now being reused in a new scheme near Felixstowe. Each year, hundreds of thousands of tonnes of drainage water which fills land near the river‚Äôs estuary is pumped away. This pumping process can also damage precious saltmarsh and mudflats, which are important habitats and part of the local ecosystem. But now, the majority of this water is being carefully pumped inland thanks to an innovative project being led locally by Suffolk County

Webinar - Simulating spatially coherent widespread flood events across the UK

Join us for presentations by Paul Sayers (Sayers & Partners) and @DrMSteel (@EnvAgency). Chaired by Prof Jason Lowe (@MetOffice_Sci).

Wednesday 24 Feb, 12-1pm

Register: https://t.co/2Xvbfl6mHq https://t.co/GjvM40D2D9

urls.title: Simulating spatially coherent widespread flood events across the UK (Webinar) -
urls.description: UK Climate Resilience Programme Webinar Series 2021 24 February 2021 Speakers: Paul Sayers (Sayers and Partners); stakeholder response from Mike Steel Chair: Jason Lowe Register for the webinar Abstract CAT modelling was developed in the late 1980s to capture the spatial correlation of extreme events, with event footprints being used to demonstrate how an extreme [‚Ä¶]

tweets.text:
In February 2020, parts of Yorkshire experienced severe flooding. As part of the @EnvAgency recovery programme, we were commissioned to produce an outline of the flooding recorded from data collected during and immediately after the events. Find out more:
https://t.co/j9woceRTrb https://t.co/76U5sQVOCh

@Jack_Hirst3 @wildlifetoursuk @WildTroutTrust @EnvAgencyYNE @DefraGovUK @YorkDalesRT @SandTCUKYorks @jaowallace @Rivers2U_ydrt @yorkshire_dales @ilkleyIain @PeteTurnerEA Indeed, organised by @YorksFarmWild

urls.title: Creation of Record Flood Outlines across Yorkshire | JBA Consulting
urls.description: Recorded Flood Outlines is a Geographical Information System (GIS) layer which shows all of the EA's records of historic flooding from rivers, the sea, groundwater and surface water. Each individual Recorded Flood Outline contains a consistent list of information about the recorded flood.

tweets.text:
We think it's important the public is told when the most serious river pollution incidents occur. 
We want the @EnvAgencySE alerts for the Lea, Brent, Crane, Roding, Colne etc. to continue. 
Sign up to help stop the service ending in March: 
https://t.co/NpDlFDfUsq

Work has begun to stabilise a riverbank damaged after the collapse of a weir at Newlay, near Leeds. The damage has not increased the immediate risk of flooding to local properties, but the works are required to prevent any further erosion and longer term flood risk. https://t.co/DJZkw0Ndxb

@ProfJGrey @wildlifetoursuk @WildTroutTrust @EnvAgencyYNE @DefraGovUK @YorkDalesRT @SandTCUKYorks @jaowallace @Rivers2U_ydrt @yorkshire_dales @ilkleyIain @PeteTurnerEA Yes, that's being done by YORgreen cic I think. Looks good stuff too!
@ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @EnvAgencyYNE @DefraGovUK @YorkDalesRT @Jack_Hirst3 @SandTCUKYorks @jaowallace @Rivers2U_ydrt @yorkshire_dales @wildlifetoursuk @ilkleyIain @PeteTurnerEA Superb!

tweets.text:
Having a 'trigger' to notify you of a #flood BEFORE it happens can allow time to prepare.

The @EnvAgencyNW Flood Warning Service is one such trigger, but do you know what the different stages mean?

Read our blog to learn more: https://t.co/5Hv1sf3FoV

#preparedness #floodaware https://t.co/7SEKTJFMnd

urls.title: Flood Alert, Flood Warning and Severe Flood Warning ‚Äì What‚Äôs the difference? | Newground
urls.description: Recently, I saw a poll on Twitter set up to help the Environment Agency understand people‚Äôs interpretation of flood risk, which is one of the reasons I decided to write this blog. Out of the 1,199 people who voted on the poll, I was quite shocked to find that 51% of voters thought a Flood Alert meant that you were at a higher risk of flooding than a Flood Warning. This is NOT the case. Raising awareness of the flood alerts and warning system and what each stage means is key to educating people and

It will:

üå± pump the water 12km to irrigate crops
